title: Locals call for action from police after helmet-wearing hoon crashes stockcar into fence
text:
Locals call for action from police after helmet-wearing hoon crashes stockcar into fence JOHN WEEKES Last updated 20:45, February 20 2017 JOHN WEEKES/FAIRFAX NZ 
A replacement fence (centre) after Friday's stockcar crash. 
Locals say a group causing trouble must be dealt to, after one of them allegedly crashed a stockcar into a fence on Friday. 
Police were called to reports of a person driving up and down several Wainuiomata, Lower Hutt, streets at about 8pm on Friday in what appeared to be a stockcar, police said. 
Witnesses believed one lime-green car and one black car did burnouts, before one crashed into a local man's fence. As of Monday afternoon, the the driver of the crashed car had not been caught or identified. JOHN WEEKES/FAIRFAX NZ 
Tire markes show where the group were doing burnouts. 
Residents said the incident was the latest in a series of events in Kowhai St, Vermont Grove and nearby areas. 
READ MORE: 
"They're going to kill someone one day," one local resident said. "It's just totally ridiculous." JOHN WEEKES/FAIRFAX NZ 
An incident in Kowhai St has sparked a police investigation and a resident says speeding drivers will kill someone unless action is taken. 
She believed the same group linked to the crash were involved in violence, and said elderly people and children in the street were at risk from the neighbourhood bullies who repeatedly drove on the street like maniacs. 
"We yell at them to slow down and they just yell abuse. Nobody will do anything about it because they're scared." 
She said at least one stockcar involved in the Friday incident was stolen. 
"The police have got to do something." 
A local man said the small antisocial group were the reason "why at night we park our cars up on the grass verge". 
He said "all the neighbours pitched in to help" the man who's fence was wrecked. 
Another local, also unwilling to be named because she feared repercussions, said the mayhem went on for some time on Friday. 
"I was putting my daughter to sleep when they went past...It sounded like the wheels locked up. Then I heard a big crash sound. Then all you heard was the wheels stuck, trying to get unstuck." 
This went on "a good five minutes," she said. 
"When they took off, they took off in a hurry." 
Several police attended from Wainuiomata and Lower Hutt. 
"It was reported that the driver of the stockcar was wearing a full helmet but shortly after crashed into a fence," a police spokeswoman said. 
"Police are aware of the area, and are undertaking investigations into the cause of the crash last Friday,' she added. 
There were no reports of any injuries resulting from the crash. ï»¿ - Stuff
